description.title: Cool It
description.description: A game about the greenhouse effect.

tutorial.select: The respiratory sphere is composed of the gases nitrogen, oxygen, argon and carbon dioxide. Light rays can pass through these gases unhindered. When a light ray hits the earth, it is absorbed by the surface and released as thermal radiation. Heat radiation is absorbed by the greenhouse gases and thus warms the atmosphere. Without these gases it would be very cold on Earth. The average temperature would be -18°C. Although the atmosphere consists of only 0.04% greenhouse gases, this is enough to warm the earth to a temperature that is comfortable for us. However, the more greenhouse gases, the warmer it gets. Gases and rays are colourless and very very small. So that you can see them, we have coloured them and enlarged them.
tutorial.play: Move the greenhouse gases out of the way to let the excess heat escape from the earth and keep it comfortable.

moleculeInfo.none: Select an available molecule to show its information.
moleculeInfo.notDiscovered: This molecule has not been discovered yet.

waterVapor.title: Water Vapor
waterVapor.pros: Up high in the atmosphere, it condenses back into liquid water and rains back down to Earth. The water we drink is part of this natural cycle.
waterVapor.cons: Water Vapor blocks heat from escaping the atmosphere, and warmer air holds more Water Vapor. Thus, as Earth heats up, more Water Vapor in the atmosphere traps more heat.

carbonDioxide.title: Carbon Dioxide
carbonDioxide.description: The main player in Earth's carbon cycle!
carbonDioxide.pros: Made up of carbon and oxygen, Carbon Dioxide is all around us naturally. It comes from decaying and living organisms as well as volcanoes.
carbonDioxide.cons: Carbon Dioxide is released when burning fossil fuels such as coal and oil. It is the most important contributor to human-caused global warming.

methane.title: Methane
methane.pros: Made of carbon and hydrogen, it is a natural gas released from wetlands, growing rice or raising cattle. Mining coal also releases natural methane pockets.
methane.cons: Methane traps a lot of heat. It is considered the second most important contributor to human-caused global warming of all the greenhouse gases.

nitrogenOxide.title: Nitrous Oxide
nitrogenOxide.pros: Nitrous Oxide is a natural part of Earth's nitrogen cycle. Bacteria in both soil and water create this gas.
nitrogenOxide.cons: Some factories, power plants and fertilizers release this gas as well. It is a powerful greenhouse gas which also damages the protective ozone layer.

ozone.title: Ozone
ozone.description: A useful shield against the sun's radiation!
ozone.pros: High up in the atmosphere, the ozone layer blocks the sun's radiation and thus protects us from those incredibly powerful rays.
ozone.cons: Closer to the ground it acts as a greenhouse gas and is usually formed by burning gas in cars or factories.

fluorinatedGases.title: Fluorinated Gases
fluorinatedGases.pros: Fluorinated Gases are usually used as a substitute to ozone-depleting substances and can be found in household appliances like refrigerators or similar. Some industries also heavily rely on these gases.
fluorinatedGases.cons: These gases do not appear naturally and are entirely synthetical. They are incredibly powerful greenhouse gases and some of them can linger in the atmosphere for a few millennia.

oxygen.title: Oxygen
oxygen.description: The one that keeps us alive.
oxygen.pros: While oxygen is not the most common gas in our atmosphere, it is the most important. Most life on Earth absorbs oxygen through breathing air which makes it an essential gas in Earth's atmosphere.
oxygen.cons: While its use in medicine is highly appreciated, oxygen is also used as combustion-sustaining element in a multitude of industries.

nitrogen.title: Nitrogen
nitrogen.description: The most common gas in Earth's atmosphere.
nitrogen.pros: Its close-to-inert nature and high availability make nitrogen a very useful gas for various applications. It is mostly used in food and chemical industries, in both its gaseous and liquid form.

argon.title: Argon
argon.pros: Argon is an inert gas and can thus be used across many different industries because of it. An example application would be the gas layer shielding the arc during arc welding.

helium.title: Helium
helium.pros: Helium is an inert gas which is of significant importance in many industries, mainly for its traits of being inert and having the lowest boiling point of any gas (-269°C).
helium.cons: Unfortunately, Helium is in high demand and short supply. On Earth it is mostly sourced from natural gas wells.

statistic.build: How often has which user created a level?
